Re: License #: CI390403045
Dear Lauryn Ritchie:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
7/17/2025. The inspection has determined substantial compliance with applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was not requested or required.
2

V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 3 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period (7/18/24-7/17/25), and compliance with each individual CAP is as
follows: The first CAP was in response to the Special Investigation
2025SIC0000356 which found a violation of CCI Rule 400.4158 Intervention
standards and prohibitions. Staff were found to have engaged in holding a youth
without being trained in restraint techniques. The CAP for this violation was
approved on 3/14/25 and involves three action steps. The first step involves all
staff being trained in the Handle with Care restraint training method. This action
step has been reviewed twice since being approved and it was documented in
each staff’s personal file that all staff were trained in the Handle with Care
techniques by the 6/11/25 unannounced visit. The second action step involved the
facility certified trainers using role-playing scenarios at every monthly mandatory
staff meeting. This was verified during unannounced quarterly meetings, and it
was found that staff meetings took place, and documentation indicates the role-
playing activity took place. The facility also provided the sign-in sheet to document
the staff in attendance, and it is noted all staff were involved. The third action step
involves a debriefing meeting occurring after each physical management incident.
Documentation indicates that since the facility has trained all staff, there have
been ten restraints and each had a documented debriefing session following the
restraint. The second CAP was in response to the Special Investigation
2025SIC0000368 which found a violation of CCI Rule 400.4109 Program
Statement. Staff were found to violate the program policy of leaving their personal
items locked in the staff office during working hours. Staff brought their personal
items out into the milieu allowing a youth to obtain medication from the staff’s
purse. The CAP for this violation was approved on 4/24/25 and involves seven
action steps. The first action step involves staff reviewing the personal belongings
section of the Code of Ethics at every monthly staff meeting. This has been
documented as occurring during two unannounced quarterly inspection. The
facility has provided a copy of the agenda and sign-in sheet for each of the
meetings that occurred. The second action step involves administration redirecting
and developing a coaching note each time staff violate this policy. Since the
approval of the CAP and documented during two unannounced quarterly
3

inspection, there have been no documentation of any violations. The third action
step involves all youth safety plans being published to the connection teams app
and reviewed during monthly staff meetings. Staff will sign when reviewing the
connection teams app and Administration will review for staff’s signatures. All of
the documented monthly staff meetings since the CAP was approved have had an
agenda and signature sheet attached which documents staff’s involvement.
Administration provided documentation of staff signing the connection teams app.
The fourth action step involves staff not signing the connection teams app within
72 hours. This will involve Administration meeting 1:1 with the staff to ensure they
understand the safety plans and signing the connections team app. During the two
unannounced quarterly inspection the facility has provided documentation of all
staff signing the connections team app after reviewing the safety plans. The fifth
action step involves the staff who brought their personal items into the milieu is to
receive disciplinary action which is placed in their personal file. During the first
unannounced quarterly inspection, it was found that this disciplinary action was in
the personal file and during the second unannounced quarterly inspection, it was
found that this staff was terminated, and the termination letter was found in the
personal file. This closes out this action step. The sixth action step involves the
staff involved being placed on a 30-day performance improvement plan with the
Chief Administrator completing weekly check-ins to review the staff’s performance.
This was documented as occurring until this staff was terminated from
employment at the facility thus ending this action step. The seventh action step
involves the Chief Administrator conducting random reviews of camera footage
during the staff involved shifts. This was documented as occurring until this staff
was terminated from her employment. This ended this action step. The third
required CAP was in response to the Special investigation 2025SIC0000512
which involved a violation of CCI Rule 400.4142-1-e Health services; policies and
procedures with an approved CAP on 6/3/25. This violation involved a youth with
multiple mental health diagnoses not being given a dose of medication as
required. The first action step involved the House Manager and/or Chief
Administrator reviewing the medication log weekly. They will document this effort
through the use of a spreadsheet and during the first unannounced quarterly
inspection it was found they are documenting their efforts to review the medication
log. The second action step involves the facility reviewing the medication policy
during the monthly staff meeting. This was reviewed during the first unannounced
quarterly visit and documented to have taken place on 6/17/25. The third action
step involves the House Manager and/or Chief Administrator providing
observations of medication procedures once a week and recording these
observations on a weekly spreadsheet. During the first unannounced quarterly
inspection during this CAP, it was documented the facility is conducting these
observations as outlined. The fourth action step involves disciplinary action for the
staff involved in the incident and a copy of the disciplinary action placed in the
staff’s personnel file. During the quarterly unannounced inspection, documentation
was found in the personnel file for the staff of the disciplinary action having taken
place. The fifth action step for this CAP involves the posting of the medication
policy in the connect team app and staff will sign acknowledgment of the policy in
4

connect team app. During the first quarterly unannounced inspection for this CAP,
this action step was found to have been completed as evidence of the observation
of the connect team app and the signatures of staff being present.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator identified the three required corrective action plans and
outlined the progress made with each one. The Chief Administrator also outlines a
CAP for 2024SIC0001334 which occurred during the prior reporting period. She
reports the impact of the action plans associated with the different CAPs has had a
positive and fruitful impact on the ability to provide appropriate and helpful services
to the youth in care. She also outlined the steps taken that were noted and
documented during the quarterly licensing inspections (see CAP compliance
above). She documents the facility had two unplanned discharges during this
reporting period with one youth being transferred to an alternative juvenile justice
program due to a probation violation and the other youth transitioned from inpatient
hospitalization to an adult foster care placement. She also documents that there
appears to be an increase in the need for mental health services with the youth
being referred and there is a struggle to find specialized treatment modalities due to
a shortage of qualified professionals causing extensive waiting lists. The Chief
Administrator notes the areas in need of improvement involve CCI Rule 400.4127
Staff to Resident ratio, Public Act 116-722.120 Investigation, inspection, and
examination of conditions., CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement, CCI Rule
400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures, and CCI Rule 400.4158
Intervention standards and prohibitions. For each of these identified areas that
could improve, the Chief Administrator documents the action steps will be that the
Chief Administrator will consult with DCWL licensing consultant as needed. Each
also identified the Chief Administrator, Quality Supervisor, Chief Operating Officer,
and Chief Regulatory Officer as responsible to ensure compliance. It appears the
choice of these areas corresponds with the special investigations that took place
during this reporting period.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviewed shared a report of a strong desire to work with the youth and
provide best practice in the youth’s care. The direct care staff interviewed are new
5

to the program and reported a very positive view of the program and administration.
They also reported receiving a significant amount of training with one staff
completing 79 hours of training since being hired in February 2025. Administration
staff interviewed reported the new staff appear very capable when dealing with
youth but also understand there could be trials and Administration is very
supportive of helping new staff through training and oversite.
Three of four youth in the program currently were interviewed with the fourth youth
staying in a local hospital under observations at this time. They reported feeling
safe at the facility and believed the program is beneficial to meet their needs. All
report receiving therapy sessions both individually and in a group setting. They
reported a belief that the staff are invested in their wellbeing and are attentive to
their needs. It should be noted that two of the youth are very new to the program.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a multiple story older facility (originally a single home) located near
downtown Kalamazoo Michigan. This structure is in constant need of maintenance
and the facility has a scheduled maintenance program to keep the building in good
repair. All required locked items (cleaning supplies, chemicals, and medications)
were found to be locked and items requiring to be posted were also found to be
posted. There was an appropriate amount of frozen, fresh, and dry food available in
the kitchen area. All plumbing was in working order and fire extinguishers were up
to date. The bedrooms were furnished appropriately as was the rest of the building.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
8/4/2025
